Award.AwardTitle: The Effects of Child Support Debt and Imprisonment on Men's Community Integration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is a comprehensive study of the intersection of the criminal justice and child support systems in the contemporary United States and its effects on men’s lives as fathers. More than half of the 2.3 million people in prison are parents, while half of them have open child support orders. How do the policies and court practices that set and enforce child support orders affect the incarcerated? What are their consequences for the parents they target? In this research, I discovered that these two state systems form feedback loops of disadvantage, creating serious obstacles for men as parents and complicating those relationships proven essential for reintegration after prison: familial relations of care, reciprocity, and interdependence.

I collected three types of data in the study. First, I analyzed data on national-level laws and policies that connect criminal justice and child support enforcement. Second, I reconstructed the legal landscape of three large states—New York, California, and Florida—which together hold a large percentage of the nation’s child support debt. I also conducted an analysis of each state’s child support system and carried out ethnographic observations of over 1200 child support hearings. Third, I conducted 125 interviews with formerly-incarcerated fathers with child support arrears in these three states.

The findings from this study fall into two general categories. The first set of findings reveal the main avenues through which the child support and criminal justice systems are linked: through debt of imprisonment and the imprisonment of debt. For the former, my research uncovered the material costs of paternal incarceration: the fathers in my sample owed an average of $36,500 in child support debt upon release from prison. This is more than double the amount owed by other disadvantaged fathers. Moreover, a range of policies underlied this debt. They include provisions that set support orders by default; policies that define incarceration as in/voluntary unemployment; provisions that set retroactive support orders; policies that charge non-custodial parents for the public assistance received by their children; and provisions that charge interest on arrears.

At the other end of prison/debt pipeline was imprisonment of debt, or entanglements that emerged from child support debt and flowed into criminal justice involvement. These encompassed all the punitive sanctions facing parents with child support debt—from wage garnishment to tax/unemployment interceptions to drivers’ license/passport revocation to judicial humiliation to imprisonment. My research showed that these practices worked together to complicate fathers’ reintegration after prison in five distinct ways: they created new barriers to employment; they put unmanageable economic pressure on fathers; they erected new obstacles to familial inclusion; they lead to system avoidance; and they increased the likelihood of criminal justice involvement.

The project’s second set of findings address the effects of these entanglements on men’s lives as parents. I uncovered several common challenges faced by formerly-incarcerated fathers, from financial to legal to emotional obstacles. Yet I also discovered that fathers navigated these challenges in different ways. There were those already-unresponsive parents who became more so when faced with these obstacles. These classic "dead beats" constituted about 10% of my sample. Second, there were men who overcame the challenges in heroic, almost superhuman, ways—they were about 20% of my sample. Finally, there were those with the best paternal intentions but who cycled in and out of their children’s lives. These “cyclical parents” constituted the large majority of fathers, roughly 70% of them. Their paternal trajectories reveal the struggles of disadvantaged fathers and the concrete barriers to social reintegration and desistance from crime.

In the end, I have used my findings to shed light on a series of social scientific debates about the familial politics of mass incarceration and the paternal politics of poverty. I have also used them to help reform both child support and criminal justice policy, particularly in the three states of the study. Finally, I hope the research will contribute to larger public debates about the effects of child support enforcement on poor men in general and formerly-incarcerated fathers in particular. My goal is to use this research to facilitate a more balanced discussion—and thus shed light on a societal problem that is consequential for so many poor parents and their families.
